posts.name: Sunay Agarwal
posts.cooked: My team is trying out a Pigeon, but we are encountering an error where after the robot stops turning, it seems to rebound in the other direction in the code a little. This seems to be a problem with the math it is doing in integrating the velocity, but that is just my guess. Any suggestions? I have noticed that the faster the robot turns, the lower it rebounds/the error is. The gyro also drifts, but it is inconsistent and probably related to the main issue. I have attached some of the data we collected. The areas where the velocity is nonzero and still flat is roughly where the “rebound” happens. tuner-plot.csv (822.5 KB)

Which pigeon are you using? Pigeon 1(officially called Pigeon IMU) or Pigeon 2. If you are using Pigeon 1, it requires temperature calibration to function properly, otherwise it might drift severely.

If you are using Pigeon 2, have you tried the Mount Calibration ?

There are times when your gyroscope may not be fixed as horizontally as it should be, resulting in an error between what the gyroscope understands as the Z-axis and what is actually the Z-axis of your machine. Mount Calibration might fix this problem.

Also, I think the signal “AccumGyroZ” might not be the proper for testing the IMU, as the official API doc says the “AccumGyroZ” stands for “The accumulated gyro about the Z axis without any sensor fusing.” meaning that the data it represent might lack some necessary process. A more proper one could simply be the “Yaw” from your pigeon.

posts.name: Sunay Agarwal
posts.cooked: Hi, we had done mount calibration, and the Yaw value gives the same error (off by less than a degree). Since the velocity doesn’t necessarily settle to zero, this could be a problem with the rotational acceleration? We are thinking the gyro might be faulty.

posts.name: Bill
posts.cooked: You should honestly just get a limelight 4 and use it’s internal IMU, I’ve heard it works a lot better than the pigeon’s and is completely independent.

IMUs are extremely temperature sensitive and will drift it not calibrated. Many IMUs have a built-in heater to regulate temperature, but since CTRE is extremely bad at documenting sensors, nobody knows if it has one or not. However, IMU sensors have advanced significantly in the past few years and I’d recommend getting a new IMU if you are using an older one.

posts.name: Eklavya Agrawal
posts.cooked:
To be concise, giving advice by saying “just buy the limelight 4” is not helpful, at all .

Limelight 4 is an all-new smart camera for FRC. It is powered by the Raspberry Pi CM5, and it’s twice as powerful as Limelight 3G out of the box. This is our biggest leap in performance yet, and it doesn’t stop there. Features:...

Price: USD 399.99

See that price? For many teams, a LL4 is not going to be in budget.

Just a tip for the future

(P.S it’s on backorder)

posts.custom_user_title: 4192 "Jack of All Trades, Master of Scouting, CAD, and BWRs"

posts.cooked:
emanresu:

Hi, we had done mount calibration, and the Yaw value gives the same error (off by less than a degree). Since the velocity doesn’t necessarily settle to zero, this could be a problem with the rotational acceleration? We are thinking the gyro might be faulty.

I think that sounds very much like a mounting issue where the Pigeon is not tightly installed on your robot and drifts slightly as the robot moves, but it could be, as you’ve said, that the pigeon itself is broken. The way to find out that is to try shaking the pigeon on your robot gently and see if the output changes.

But I’d say, from my personal experience, that offset in less than a degree won’t necessarily affect your robot’s auto performance. If you can’t fix the problem in the end, just ignore that or try adding a reset button if your tele-op experience is affected.

I remember a team using an IMU that hadn’t gone through mounting calibration and would drift for 30 degrees per rotation but still scored high in the game. So I think the problem is not quite critical.
